publicationStmt.publisher: Wit without money A comedie, at it hath beene presented with good applause at the private house in Drurie Lane, by her Majesties Servants. Written by Francis Beaumount, and Iohn Flecher. Gent. , London : Printed by Thomas Cotes, for Andrew Crooke, and William Cooke, 1639 [i.e. 1640] Date: 1640 Bib name / number: STC (2nd ed.) / 1691 Bib name / number: Greg, II, 563(a). / Physical description: [64] p. Copy from: British Library

sourceDesc.p:
Play details
Wit without money. Genre: Comedy. Date first published: 1639. Date first performed: 1614-1616.

encodingDesc.p: The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Merchant. Uncle. Fountaine. Bellamore. Harebraine. Lance. Vallentine. Luce. Isabell. Franscisco. Tennants. Widdow. 1 Servant. 2 Servant. Shorthouse. Roger. Ralph. Humphrey. Walter. Musician. multiple voice/Fountaine/Harebraine.

langUsage.p: l The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.l: When saw you Valentine

sp.speaker: Uncle.
sp.l: Not since the Horserace, he is taken up with those that woo the Widow.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: How can, he live by snatches from such people? he bore a worthy mind.

sp.speaker: Uncle.
sp.l: Alas, he is sunk, his means are gone, he wants, and which is worse,
Takes a delight in doing so.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: That is strange.

sp.speaker: Unc.
sp.l: Runs Lunatic, if you but talk of states, he cannot be brought now he has spent his own to think there is inheritance, or means, but all a common riches, all men bound to be his Bailiffs.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: This is something dangerous.

sp.speaker: Uncle.
sp.l: No Gentleman that has estate to use, it in keeping house, or followers, for those ways he cries against, for eating sins, dull surfeits, cramming of serving men, mustering of beggars, maintain hospitals for Kites, and curs, grounding their fat faiths upon old Country proverbs, God bless the founders; these he would have ventured into more manly uses, Wit, and carriage, and never thinks of state, or means, the ground works: holding it monstrous, men should feed their bodies, and starve their understandings.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: That is most certain.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.l: Yes, if he could stay there.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Why let him marry, and that way rise again.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.l: It is most impossible, he will not look with any handsomeness upon a woman.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Is he so strange to women.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.l: I know not what it is, a foolish glory he has got, I know not where, to balk those benefits, and yet he will converse and flatter them, make them, or fair, or foul, rugged, or smooth, as his impression serves, for he affirms, they are only lumps, and undigested pieces, licked over to a form, by our affections, and then they show; The lovers let them pass.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: He might be one, he carries as much promise; they are wondrous merry.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.l: O their hopes are high sir.

sp.speaker: Fount.
sp.l: Is Vallentine come to Town?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Last night I heard.

sp.speaker: Fount.
sp.l: We miss him monstrously in our directions, for this Widow, is as stately, and as crafty, and stands I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Haire.
sp.l: Let her stand sure, she falls before us else, come let us go seek Vallentine.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: This Widow seems a gallant:

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.l: A goodly woman, and to her handsomeness she bears her state, reserved, and great Fortune has made her Mistress of a full means, and well she knows to use it.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I would Vallentine had her.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.l: There is no hope of that Sir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: A that condition, he had his Mortgage in again.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.l: I would he had.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Seek means, and see what I will do, however let the money be paid in, I never sought a Gentleman's undoing, nor eat the bread of other men's vexations, the mortgage shall be rendered back , take time fore, you told me of another brother:

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.l: Yes sir, more miserable than he, for he has eat him, and drunk him up, a handsome Gentleman, and fine Scholar.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: What are these?

sp.speaker: Unc.
sp.l: The tenants, they will do what they can,

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: It is well prepared, be earnest, honest friends, and loud upon him, he is deaf to his own good.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.l: We mean to tell him part of our minds if it please you.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Do, and do it home, and in what my care may help, or my persuasions when we meet next.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: Do but persuade him fairly; and for your money, mine, and these men's thanks too, and what we can be able:

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: You are most honest, you shall find me no less, and so I leave you, prosper your business my friends.

sp.speaker: Unc.
sp.l: Pray heaven it may sir:

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Nay if he will be mad, I will be mad with him, and tell him that I will not spare him, his Father kept good meat, good drink, good fellows, good hawks, good hounds, and bid his neighbours welcome; kept him too, and supplied his prodigality, yet kept his state still; must we turn Tenants now, after we have lived under the race of Gentry, and maintained good yeomanry, to some of the City, to a great shoulder of Mutton, and a Custard, and have our state turned into Cabbage Gardens, must it be so:

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.l: You must be milder to him.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.l: That is as he makes his game.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.l: Entreat him lovingly, and make him feel.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.l: I will pinch him to the bones else.

sp.speaker: Vallen.
sp.l: And tell the Gentleman, I will be with him presently, say I want money too, I must not fail boy.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.l: You will want clothes, I hope.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.l: Bid the young Courtier repair to me anon, I will read to him.

sp.speaker: Unc.
sp.l: He comes, be diligent, but not too rugged, start him, but affright him not.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.l: Phew, are you there?

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.l: We come to see you Nephew, be not angry;

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Why do you dog me thus, with these strange people, why, all the world shall never make me rich more, nor master of these troubles.

sp.speaker: Tennants.
sp.l: We beseech you for our poor children's sake.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Who bid you get them: have you not thrashing work enough, but children must be baugd out of the sheaf too, other men with all their delicates, and healthful diets, can get but wind eggs: you with a clove of garlic, a piece of cheese would break a saw, and sour milk, and I must maintain these tumblers.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: You ought to maintain us, we have maintained you, and when you slept provided for you; who bought the silk you wear, I think our labours; reckon, you will find it so: who found your horses perpetual pots of ale, maintained your Taverns, and who extolled you in the half crown boxes, where you might sit and muster all the beauties, we had no hand in these; no, we are puppies: Your tenants base vexations.

sp.speaker: Uall.
sp.l: Very well, sir.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Had you Land, and honest men to serve your purposes, honest, and faithful, and will you run away from them, betray yourself, and your poor tribe to misery; mortgage all us, like old cloaks; where will you hunt next, you had a thousand acres, fair and open: The Kings bench is enclosed, there is no good riding, the Counter is full of thorns and brakes; take heed sir, and bogs, you will quickly find what broth they are made of.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You are short and pithy.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: They say you are a fine Gentleman, and excellent judgment, they report you have a wit; keep yourself out of the rain and take your Cloak with you, which by interpretation is your state sir, or I shall think your fame belied you, you have money, and may have means.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I prithee leave prating, does my good lie within thy brain to further, or my undoing in thy pity: go, go, get you home, there whistle to your horses, and let them edify; away, sow hemp, and hang yourselves withal;, what am I to you, or you to me; am I your Landlord, puppies?

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.l: This is uncivil.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: More unmerciful you, to vex me with these bacon broth and puddings, they are the walking shapes of all my sorrows.

sp.speaker: Tennants.
sp.l: Your Fathers Worship, would have used us better.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My Fathers worship, was a fool.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.l: Hey, hey boys, old Vallentine in faith, the old boy still.

sp.speaker: Unc.
sp.l: Fie Cousin.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I mean besotted to his state, he had never left me the misery of so much means else, which till I sold, was a mere meagrome to me: If you will talk, turn out these tenements, they are as killing to my nature Uncle, as water to a fever.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: We will go, but it is like Rams, to come again the stronger, and you shall keep your state.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: Thou liest, I will not.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.l: Sweet sir, thou liest, thou shalt, and so good morrow.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: This was my man, and of a noble breeding: now to your business Uncle.

sp.speaker: Unc.
sp.l: To your state then.

sp.speaker: Val,
sp.p: It is gone, and I am glad on it, name it no more, it is that I pray against, and heaven has heard me, I tell you, sir, I am more fearful of it, I mean, of thinking of more lands, or livings, than sickly men are travelling a Sundays, for being quelled with Carriers out upon it caveat emptor, let the fool out sweat it, that thinks he has got a catch on it.

sp.speaker: Unc.
sp.l: This is madness to be a wilful beggar.

sp.speaker: Ua.
sp.p: I am mad then and so I mean to be, will that content you, how bravely now I live, how jocund, how near the first inheritance, without fears, how free from title-troubles!

sp.speaker: Unc.
sp.l: And from means too.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.p: Means, why all good men's my means; my wits my plough, the Town is my stock, Taverne is my standing house, and all the world knows there is no want; all Gentlemen that love Society, love me; all purses that wit and pleasure opens, are my Tenants; every man's clothes fit me, the next fair lodging, is but my next remove, and when I please to remove; and when I please to be more eminent, and take the air, a piece is levied, and a Coach prepared, and I go I care not whether, what need state here.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.l: But say these means were honest, will they last sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Far longer than your jerkin, and wear fairer, should I take aught of you, it is true, I begged now, or which is worse than that, I stole a kindness, and which is worst of all, I lost my way in it, your mind is enclosed, nothing lies open nobly, your very thoughts are hid, that work on nothing but daily sweat, and trouble: were my way so full of dirt as this, it is true I shifted; are my acquaintance Graziers but sir, know, no man that I am allied to, in my living, but makes it equal, whether his own use, or my necessity pull first, nor is this forced, but the mere quality and poysure of goodness, and do you think I venture nothing equal.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.l: You pose me Cousin.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.p: What is my knowledge Uncle, is it not worth money, what is my understanding, my travel, reading, wit, all these digested, my daily making men, some to speak, that too much phlegm had frozen up, some other that spoke too much, to hold their peace, and put their tongues to pensions, some to wear their clothes, and some to keep them, these are nothing Uncle; besides these ways, to teach the way of nature, a manly love, community to all that are deservers, not examining how much, or what is done for them, it is wicked, and such a one like you, chews his thoughts double, making them only food for his repentance.

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.l: This cloak and hat sir, and my Masters love.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: Commend this to thy Master, and take that, and leave them at my lodging.

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.l: I shall do it sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I do not think of these things:

sp.speaker: 2. Ser.
sp.l: Please you sir, I have gold here for you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Give it me, drink that and commend me to thy Master; look you Uncle, do I beg these:

sp.speaker: Unc.
sp.l: No sure, it is your worth, sir.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.p: It is like enough, but pray satisfy me, are not these ways as honest as persecuting the starved inheritance, with musty Corn, the very rats were fain to run away from, or selling rotten wood by the pound, like spices, which Gentlemen do after burn by the ounces, do not I know your way of feeding beasts, with grains, and windy stuff, to blow up butchers, your racking pastures, that have eaten up as many singing Shepherds, and their issues, as Andeluria breeds; these are authentic, I tell you sir, I would not change ways with you, unless it were to sell your state, that hour, and if it were possible to spend it then too, for all your Beans in Rumnillo, now you know me.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: I would you knew yourself, but since you are grown such a strange enemy, to all that fits you, give me leave to make your brothers fortune.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.l: From your mortgage, which yet you may recover, I will find the means.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.p: Pray save your labour sir, my brother and myself, will run one fortune, and I think what I hold a mere vexation, cannot be safe from; him, I love him better, he has wit at will, the world has means, he shall live without this trick of state, we are heirs both, and all the world before us.

sp.speaker: Unc.
sp.l: My last offer, and then I am gone.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What is it, and then I will answer.

sp.speaker: Unc.
sp.l: What think you of a Wife yet to restore you, and tell me seriously without these trifles.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: If you can find one, that can please my fancy, you shall not find me stubborn.

sp.speaker: Unc.
sp.l: Speak your woman.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.p: One without eyes, that is self-commendations, for when they find they are handsome, they are unwholesome, one without ears, not giving time to flatterers, for she that hears herself commended, wavers, and points men out a way to make them wicked; one without substance of herself; that woman without the pleasure of her life, that is wanton; though she be young, forgetting it, though fair, making her glass the eyes of honest men, not her own admiration, all her ends obedience, all her hours new blessings, if there may be such a woman.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.l: Yes there may be.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And without state too.

sp.speaker: Unc.
sp.l: You are disposed to trifle, well, fare you well sir, when you want me next, you will seek me out a better sense.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Farewell Uncle, and as you love your estate, let not me hear of it .

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.l: It shall not trouble you, I will watch him still,
And when his friends fall off , then bend his will.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: I know the cause of all this sadness now, your sister has engrossed all the brave lovers.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: She has wherewithal, much good may do her, prithee speak softly, we are open to men's ears:

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Fear not, we are safe, we may see all that pass, hear all, and make ourselves merry with their language, and yet stand undiscovered, be not melancholy, you are as fair as she.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Who I? I thank you, I am as haste ordained me a thing slubberd, my sister is a goodly portly Lady, a woman of a presence, she spreads satin, as the Kings ships do canvas, everywhere , she may spare me her mizzen, and her bonnets, strike her maine petticoat, and yet outsail me, I am a Caravel to her.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: But a tight one:

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: She is excellent, well built too.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: And yet she is old.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: She never saw above one voyage Luce, and credit me after another, her hull will serve again, a right good Merchant, she plays, and sings too, dances and discourses, comes very near essays a pretty poet, begins to piddle with Philosophy, a subtle Chimicke wench, and can extract the spirit of men's estates, she has the light before her, and cannot miss her choice, for me it is reason, I wait my mean fortune.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: You are so bashful.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: It is not at first word up and ride, thou art cozened; that would show mad infaith , besides, we lose the mean part of our politic government, if we become provokers, then we are fair, and fit for men's embraces, when like towns, they lie before us ages, yet not carried, hold out their strongest batteries, then compound too with the loss of honour, and march oft with our fair wedding: Colours flying, who are these?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: I know not, nor I care not.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Prithee peace then, a well built Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: But poorly thatched.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.l: Has he devoured you too?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Has gulped me down Lance.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.l: Left you no means to study.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Not a farthing: dispatched my poor annuity I thank him, here is all the hope I have left, one bare ten shillings.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: You are fit for great men's services.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I am fit, but who will take me, thus men's miseries are now accounted stains in their natures, I have travelled, and I have studied long, observed all kingdoms, know all the promises of Art and manners, yet that I am not bold, nor cannot flatter, I shall not thrive, all these are but vain Studies, art thou so rich as to get me a lodging Lance.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: I will sell the titles of my house else, my Horse, my Hawk, nay's death I will pawn my wife: O Mr Francis, that I should see your Fathers house fall thus!

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: An honest fellow.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Your Fathers house, that fed me, that bred up all my name.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: A grateful fellow.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: And fall by.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Peace, I know you are angry Lance, but I must not hear with whom, he is my Brother, and though you hold him slight, my most dear brother: A gentleman excepting some few rubs, he were too excellent to live here else, fraughted as deep with noble and brave parts, the issues of a noble and manly spirit, as any he alive , I must not hear you, though I am miserable, and he made me so, yet still he is my brother, still I love him, and to that tie of blood link my affections.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: A noble nature, dost thou know him Luce?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: No Mistress.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Thou shouldst ever know such good men, what a fair body and mind, are married there together; did he not say he wanted.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: What is that to you?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: It is true, but it is great pity.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: How she changes, ten thousand more than he, as handsome men too.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: It is like enough, but as I live, this Gentleman among ten thousand thousand, is there no knowing him; why should he want? fellows of no merit, slight and past souls, that walk like shadows, by leaving no print of what they are, or poise, let them complain.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Her colour changes strangely.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: This man was made, to mark his wants to waken us, alas poor Gentleman, but will that keep him from cold, believe me he is well bred, and cannot be but of a noble lineage, mark him, mark him well.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: He is a handsome man.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: The sweetness of his sufferance sets him off, O Luce, but whether go I.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: You cannot hide it.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: I would he had what I can spare.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: It is charitable.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Come Sir, I will see you lodged, you have tied my tongue fast, I will steal before you want, it is but a hanging.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: That is a good fellow too, an honest fellow, why, this would move a stone, I must needs know; but that some other time.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Is the wind there? that makes for me.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Come, I forgot a business.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: My sister, and a woman of so base a pity, what was the fellow?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Why, an ordinary man, Madam.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Poor?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Poor enough, and no man knows from whence neither.

sp.speaker: Wed.
sp.l: What could she see?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Only his misery, for else she might behold a hundred handsomer.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Did she change much.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Extremely, when he spoke, and then her pity, like an Orator, I fear her love framed such a commendation, and followed it so far, as made me wonder.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Is she so hot, or such a want of lovers, that she must dote upon afflictions: why does she not go rummage all the Prisons, and there bestow her youth, bewray her wantonness, and fly her honour, common both to beggary; did she speak to him?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: No, he saw us not, but ever since, she hath been mainly troubled.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Was he young?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Yes young enough.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: And looked he like a gentleman?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Like such a Gentleman, would pawn ten oaths for twelve pence.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: My sister, and sink basely; this must not be, does she use means to know him?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Yes Madam, and has employed a Squire called Shorthose.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: O that is a precious Knave, keep all this private, but still be near her lodging; Luce what you can gather by any means, let me understand, I will stop her heat, and turn her charity another way, to bless herself first, be still close to her Counsels, a beggar and a stranger, there is a blessedness, I will none of that; I have a toy yet sister, shall tell you this is soul, and make you find it, and for your pains take you the last gown I wore, this makes me mad, but I shall force a remedy.

sp.speaker: Fount.
sp.p: Sirrah, we have so looked thee, and longed for thee; this Widow is the strangest thing, the stateliest, and stands so much upon her excellencies.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: She hath put us off this month now, for an answer.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.l: No man must visit her, nor look upon her, not say, good morrow, nor good even, till that is past.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p: She has found what dough you are made of, and so kneads you, are you good at nothing, but these aftergames, I have told you often enough what things they are, what precious things, these widows.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.l: If we had them.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Why the devil has not craft enough to woe them, there be three kinds of fools, mark this note gentlemen, mark it, and understand it.

sp.speaker: Fount.
sp.l: Well, go forward.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: An Innocent, a Knave fool, a fool politic: the last of which are lovers, widow lovers.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Will you allow no Fortune?

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: No such blind one.

sp.speaker: Fount.
sp.l: We gave you reasons, why it was needful for us.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.p: As you are those fools, I did allow those reasons, but as my Scholars and companions damned them, do you know what it is to woo a widow, answer me coolly now, and understandingly.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.l: Why to lie with her, and to enjoy her wealth.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.p: Why there you are fools still, crafty to catch yourselves, pure politic fools, I looked for such an answer, once more hear me, it is to wed a widow, to be doubted mainly, whether the state you have be yours or no, are those old boots you ride in, mark me, widows are long extents in Law upon news, livings upon their bodies winding-sheets, they that enjoy them, lie but with dead men's monuments, and beget only their own ill Epitaphs, Is not this plain now?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Plain spoken.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.p: And plain truth, but if you will needs do things of danger, do but lose yourselves, not any part concerns your understandings, for then you are Meacocks, fools, and miserable, march of a maine, within an inch of a Fircug, turn me other toe like a Weathercock, kill every day a Sergeant for a twelve month, rob the Exchequer, and burn all the rolls, and these will make a show.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.l: And these are trifles.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Considered to a Widow, empty nothing, for here you venture but your persons, there the varnish of your persons, your discretions; why it is a monstrous thing to marry at all, especially as now it is made, methinks a man, an understanding man, is more wise to me, and of a nobler tie, than all these trinkets, what do we get by women, but our senses, which is the rankest part about us satisfied, and when that is done what are we? Crest fallen cowards, what benefit can children be, but charges and disobedience, what is the love they render at one and twenty years; I pray die father; when they are young, they are like bells rung backwards, nothing but noise, and giddiness; and come to years once, there drops a son by the sword in his Mistresses quarrel, a great joy to his parents: a daughter ripe too, grows high and lusty in her blood, must have a heating, runs away with a supple hand Serving-man, his twenty nobles spent, takes to a trade, and learns to spin men's haire off; there is another, and most are of this nature, will you marry?

sp.speaker: Fount.
sp.l: For my part yes, for any doubt I feel yet.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And this same widow?

sp.speaker: Fount.
sp.p: If I may, and methinks , however you are pleased to dispute these dangers, such a warm match, and for you sir, were not hurtful.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Not half so killing as for you, for me she cannot with all the Art she has, make me more miserable, or much more fortunate, I have no state left, a benefit that none of you can brag of, and there is the Antidote against a Widow, nothing to lose, but that my soul inherits, which she can neither law nor claw away to that, but little flesh, it were too much else; and that unwholesome too, it were too rich else; and to all this contempt of what she does I can laugh at her tears, neglect her angers, hear her without a faith, so pity her as if she were a traitor, moan her person, but deadly hate her pride; if you could do these, and had but this discretion, and like fortune, it were but an equal venture.

sp.speaker: Fount.
sp.l: This is malice.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.p: When she lies with your land, and not with you, grows great with jointures, and is brought to bed with all the state you have, you will find this certain; but is it come to pass you must marry, is there no buff will hold you?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Grant it be so.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Then choose the tamer evil, take a maid, a maid not worth a penny; make her yours, knead her, and mold her yours, a maid worth nothing, there is a virtuous spell, in that word nothing; a maid makes conscience of half a crown a week for pins and puppets, a maid content with one Coach and two horses, not falling out because they are not matches; with one man satisfied, with one rain guided, with one faith, one content, one bed, aged she makes the wife, preserves the fame and issue; a Widow is a Christmas box that sweeps all.

sp.speaker: Fount.
sp.l: Yet all this cannot sink us.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You are my friends, and all my loving friends, I spend your money, yet I deserve it too, you are my friends still, I ride your horses, when I want I sell them; I eat your meat, help to wear her linen, sometimes I make you drunk, and then you seal, for which I will do you this commodity, be ruled, and let me try her, I will discover her, the truth is, I will never leave to trouble her, till I see through her, then if I find her worthy.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.l: This was our meaning Valentine.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: It is done then, I must want nothing.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.l: Nothing but the woman.

sp.speaker: Val.
Isa.
sp.l: But art thou sure?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: No surer than I heard.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.l: That it was that flouting fellows brother?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Yes, Shorthose told me so.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.l: He did search out the truth?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: It seems he did.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Prithee Luce, call him hither, if he be no worse, I never repent my pity, now sirrah, what was he we sent you after, the Gentleman in the black.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: In the torn black?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Yes, the same sir.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: What would your Worship with him.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Why my worship would know his name, and what he is.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: He is nothing, he is a man, and yet he is no man.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: You must needs play the fool.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: It is my profession.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: How is he a man, and no man.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: He is a beggar, only the sign of a man, the bush pulled down, which shows the house stands empty.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: What is his calling?

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: They call him beggar:

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: What is his kindred:

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: Beggars.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: His worth.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: A learned beggar, a poor Scholar.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: How does he live.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: Like worms, he eats old Books.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Is Valentine his brother.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: His begging brother.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: What may his name be?

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: Orson.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Leave your fooling.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: You had as good say, leave your living.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Once more tell me his name directly.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: I will be hanged first, unless I heard him Christened, but I can tell what foolish people call him.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: Francisco.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Where lies this learning sir?

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: In Paules Church yard forsooth.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: I mean the Gentleman, fool.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: O that fool, he lies in loose sheets everywhere, that is nowhere.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: You have gleaned since you came to London, in the Country Shorthose, you were an arrant fool, a dull cold coxcomb, here every Tavern teaches you, the pint pot has so belaboured you, with wit, your brave acquaintance that gives you ale, so fortified your mazard, that now there is no talking to you.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Is much improved, a fellow, a fine discourser.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: I hope so, I have not waited at the tail of wit, so long to be an ass.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: But say now Shorthose , my Lady should remove into the Country.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: I had as lief she should remove to heaven, and as soon I would undertake to follow her.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Where no old Charnico is, nor no Anchovies, no Master such a one, to meet at the Rose, and bring my Lady, such a ones chief Chambermaid.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: No bouncing healths to this brave Lad, dear Shorthose, nor down on the knees to that illustrious Lady.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: No fiddles, nor no lusty noise of drawer, carry this pottle to my father Shorthose.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: No plays, nor galley foists, no strange Ambassadors to run and wonder at, till thou beest oil, and then come home again, and lie by the Legend.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Say she should go.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: If I say, I will be hanged first, or if I thought she would go:

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: I would go with her.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: But Shorthose, where thy heart is:

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Do not fright him.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: By this hand Mistress it is a noise, a loud one too, and from her own mouth, presently to be gone too, but why, or to what end?

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: May not a man die first, she will give him so much time.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Gone of the sudden; thou dost but jest, she must not mock the Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: She has put them off a month, they dare not see her, believe me Mistress, what I hear I tell you.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Is this true wench, gone on so short a warning, what trick is this, she never told me of it, it must not be: sirrah, attend me presently, you know I have been a careful friend unto you, attend me in the hall, and next be faithful cry not, we shall not go.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: Her Coach may crack.

sp.speaker: Uall.
sp.l: Which way to live, how darest thou come to town, to ask such an idle question.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Methinks it is necessary, unless you could restore that annuity you have tippled up in Taverns.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Where hast thou been, and how brought up Franscisco, that thou talkest thus out of France, thou wert a pretty fellow, and of a handsome knowledge; who has spoiled thee:

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: He that has spoiled himself , to make himself sport, and by his Copy, will spoil all comes near him, buy but a glass, if you be yet so wealthy, and look there who?

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: Well said old Copyhold.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: My heart is good freehold sir, and so you will find it, this Gentleman your Brother, your hopeful brother, for there is no hope of you, use him thereafter.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: Even as well as I use myself, what wouldst thou have Francke.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Can you procure me a hundred pound:

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Hark what he says to you, O try your wits, they say you are excellent at it, for your land has lain long bed rid, and insensible.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: And I will forget all wrongs, you see my state, and to what wretchedness, your will has brought me; but what it may be, by this benefit, if timely done, and like a noble brother, both you and I may feel, and to our comforts:

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: (A hundred pound) dost thou know what thou hast said boy:

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I said a hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.p: Thou hast said more, than any man can justify, believe it, procure a hundred pounds, I say to thee, there is no such sum in nature, forty shillings there may be now in the Mint, and that is a treasure, I have seen five pound, but let me tell it, and it is as wonderful, as Calves with five legs, here is five shillings Francke, the harvest of five weeks, and a good crop too, take it, and pay thy first fruits, I will come down and eat it out.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: It is patience must meet with you sir, not love.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Deal roundly, and leave these fiddle faddles:

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: Leave thy prating, thou thinkest thou art a notable wise fellow, thou and thy rotten Sparrow hawk; two of the reverent.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: I think you are mad, or if you be not, will be, with the next moon, what would you have him do.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: To get money first, that is to live, you have showed him how to want.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: 'slife how do I live, why, what dull fool would ask that question, three hundred three pilds more, I and live bravely, the better half of the town, and live most gloriously, ask them what states they have, or what annuities, or when they pray for seasonable harvests, thou hast a handsome wit, stir into the world, Francke, stir, stir, for shame, thou art a pretty Scholar, ask how to live, write, write, write anything, the world is a fine believing world, write news.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Dragons in Sussex sir, or fiery battles seen in the air at Aspurge.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: There is the way Francke, and in the tail of these, fright me the Kingdom with a sharpe Prognostication, that shall scour them, dearth upon dearth, like leaven taffetas, predictions of Sea breaches, wars, and want of herrings on our coast, with bloody noses.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Whirl winds, that shall take off the top of Grantam steeple, and clap it on Poules, and after these, a Lenvoy to the City for their sins.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Probatum est, thou canst not want a pension, go switch me up a Covey of young Scholars, there is twenty nobles, and two loads of coals, are not these ready ways. Cosmography thou art deeply read in, draw me a map from the Mermaid, I mean a midnight map to scape the watches, and such long senseless examinations, and Gentlemen shall feed thee, right good Gentlemen, I cannot stay long.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: You have read learnedly, and would you have him follow these megeras, did you begin with ballads?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Well, I will leave you, I see my wants are grown ridiculous, yours may be so, I will not curse you neither; you may think, when these wanton fits are over, who bred me, and who ruined me, look to yourself, sir, a providence I wait on.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Thou art passionate, hast thou been brought up with girls.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: Rest you merry Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Not so merry as you suppose sir.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: Pray stay a while, and let me take a view of you, I may put my spoon into the wrong pottage pot else.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why wilt thou muster us.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: No you are not he, you are a thought too handsome.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Who wouldst thou speak withal, why doest thou peep so?

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: I am looking birds nests, I can find none in your bush beard, I would speak with you, black Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: With me my friend?

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: Yes sure, and the best friend sir, it seems you spake withal this twelve months Gentleman, there is money for you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: There is none for you sir, be not so brief, not a penny, law how he itches at it, stand off , you stir my colour.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Take it, it is money.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: You are too quick too, first be sure you have it, you seem to be a Falconer, but a foolish one.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Take it, and say nothing:

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: You are cozened too, it is take it, and spend it.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: From whom came it sir.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: Such another word, and you shall have none on it.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I thank you sir, I doubly thank you.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: Well sir, then buy you better clothes, and get your hat dressed, and your Laundress to wash your boots white.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Pray stay sir, may you not be mistaken.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: I think I am, give me the money again, come quick, quick, quick.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I would be loath to render, till I am sure it be so.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: Hark in your ear, is not your name Franscisco.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: Be quiet then, it may thunder a hundred times, before such stones fall; do you not need it?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: And it is thought you have it.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I think I have.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Then hold it fast, it is not fly-blown, you may pay for the poundage, you forget yourself, I have not seen a Gentleman so backward, a wanting Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Your mercy sir.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: Friend you have mercy, a whole bag full of mercy, be merry with it, and be wise.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I would fain if it please you, but know.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: It does not please me, tell over your money and be not mad boy.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You have no more such bags:

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: More such there are sir, but few I fear for you, I have cast your water, you have wit, you need no money.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Be not amazed sir it is good gold, good old gold, this is restorative, and in good time, it comes to do you good, keep it and use it, let honest fingers feel it, yours be too quick sir.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: He named me, and he gave it me, but from whom.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Let them send more, and then examine it, this can be but a preface.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Being a stranger, of whom can I deserve this.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Sir, of any man that has but eyes, and manly understanding to find men's wants, good men are bound to do so.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Now you see, Francke, there are more ways than certainties, now you believe: What plough brought you this harvest, what sale of timber, coals, or what annuities, these feed no hinds, nor wait the expectation of quarter days, you see it showers into you, you are an ass, lie plodding, and lie fooling, about this blazing star, and that bo peep, whining, and fasting, to find the natural reason why a dog turns twice about before he lie down, what use of these, or what joy in annuities, where every man is thy study, and thy tenant, I am ashamed on thee:

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Yes I have seen this fellow, there is a wealthy Widow hard by.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Yes marry is there.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: I think he is her servant, I am cozened if after her, I am sure on it.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I am glad on it.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: She is a good woman.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I am gladder.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: And young enough believe.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I am gladder of all sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Franck, you shall lie with me soon .

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I thank my money:

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: His money shall lie with me, three in a bed sir will be too much this weather.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Meet me at the Mermaid, and thou shalt see what things ~~

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Trust to yourself sir.

sp.speaker: Fount.
sp.l: O Vallentine.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: How now, why do you look so.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: The Widow is going man.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why let her go man.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.l: She is going out of the Town.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: The Town is the happier, I would they were all gone.

sp.speaker: Fount.
sp.l: We cannot come to speak with her.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: Not to speak to her.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: She will be gone within this hour, either now Valle.

sp.speaker: Fount.Hare.
sp.l: Now, now, now, good Vall.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I had rather march in the mouth of the Cannon, but adieu, if she be above ground, go, away to your prayers, away I say, away, she shall be spoken withal.

body.stage: Enter Shorthose with one boot on, Roger and Humphrey.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: She will go Shorthose.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: Who can help it Roger?

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: Roger help down with the hangings.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: By and by Raph, I am making up of the trunks here.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: Shorthose.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: Well.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: Who looks to my Ladies Wardrobe? Humphrey.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: Down with the boxes in the gallery, and bring away the Coach Cushions.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: Will it not rain, no conjuring abroad, nor no devices to stop this journey.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Why go now, why now, why of the sudden, now what preparation, what horses have we ready, what provision laid in in the Country.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Not an egg I hope.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: No nor one drop of good drink boys, there is the devil.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: I heartily pray the malt be musty, and then we must come up again.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: What says the Steward?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: He is at his wits end, for some four hours since, out of his haste and providence, he mistook the Millers mangy mare, for his own nag.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: And she may break his neck, and save the journey, O London how I love thee.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: I have no boots, nor none I will buy (or if I had) refuse me if I would venture my ability, before a cloak bag, men are men.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: For my part, if I be brought, as I know it will be aimed at, to carry any dirty dairy cream pot, or any gentle Lady of the Laundry, chambering, or wantonness behind my gelding, with all her streamers, knapsacks, glasses, gewgaw's, as if I were a running slippery, I will give them leave to cut my girts, and slay me. I will not be troubled with their distibations, at every half miles end, I understand myself , and am resolved.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: Tomorrow night at Olivers, who shall be there boys, who shall meet the wenches.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: The well brewed stand of Ale, we should have met at.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: These griefs like to another tale of Troy, would mollify the hearts of barbarous people, and Tom Butcher weep Eneas enters, and now the town is lost.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: Why whether run you, my Lady is mad.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: I would she were in Bedlam.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.p: The carts are come, no hands to help to load them, the stuff lies in the hall, the plate:

sp.speaker: Widdow.
sp.l: Why knaves there, where be these idle fellows

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: Shall I ride with one boot.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Why where I say:

sp.speaker: Ral.
sp.l: Away, away, it must be so.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: O for a tickling storm, to last but ten days.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: By my troth Mistress I did it for the best.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: It may be so, but Luce, you have a tongue: a dish of meat in your mouth, which if it were minced Luce, would do a great deal better.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I protest Mistress.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: It will be your own one time or other: Walter.

sp.speaker: Walter
sp.l: Anon forsooth.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Lay my hat ready, my fan and cloak, you are so full of providence; and Walter, tuck up my little box behind the Coach, and bid my maid make ready, my sweet service to your good Lady Mistress; and my dog, good let the Coachman carry him.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: But hear me.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I am in love sweet Luce, and you are so skilful, that I must needs undo myself; and hear me, let Oliver pack up my glass discreetly, and see my Curls well carried, O sweet Luce, you have a tongue, and open tongues have open you know what Luce.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Pray you be satisfied.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Yes and contented too, before I leave you: there is a Roger, which some call a Butcher, I speak of certainties, I do not fish Luce, nay do not stare, I have a tongue can talk too: and a green Chamber Luce, a back door opens to a long gallery; there was a night Luce, do you perceive, do you perceive me yet: O do you blush Luce: a Friday night I saw your Saint Luce; for the other box of Marmalade, all is thine sweet Roger, this I heard and kept too.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Even as you are a woman Mistress.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: This I allow as good and physical sometimes these meetings, and for the cheering of the heart, but Luce, to have your own turn served, and to your friend to be a dogbolt.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: I confess it Mistress.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: As you have made my sister Jealous of me, and foolishly, and childishly pursued it, I have found out your haunt, and traced your purposes, for which mine honour suffers, your best ways must be applied to bring her back again , and seriously and suddenly, that so I may have a means to clear myself, and she a fair opinion of me, else, you peevish ~~

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: My power and prayers Mistress.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: What is the matter.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: I have been with the Gentleman, he has it, much good may do him with it.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Come, are you ready, you love so to delay time, the day grows on.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: I have sent for a few trifles, when those are come; And now I know your reason.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Know your own honour then, about your business, see the Coach ready presently, I will tell you more then;

And understand it well, you must not think my sister, so tender eyed as not to see your follies, alas I know your heart, and must imagine, and truly too; it is not your charity can coin such sums to give away as you have done, in that you have no wisdom Isabel, no nor modesty, where nobler uses are at home; I tell you, I am ashamed to find this in your years, far more in your discretion, none to choose but things for pity, none to seal your thoughts on, but one of no abiding, of no name; nothing to bring you but this, cold and hunger: A jolly Jointure sister, you are happy, no money, no not ten shillings.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: You search nearly.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: I know it as I know your folly, one that know not where he shall eat his next meal, take his rest, unless it be in the stocks; what kindred has he, but a more wanting brother, or what virtues.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: You have had rare intelligence, I see, sister.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Or say the man had virtue, is virtue in this age a full inheritance: what Jointure can he make you, Plutarebs Morals, or so much penny rent in the small pots, this is not well, it is weak, and I grieve to know it.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: And this you quit the town for?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: It is not time.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: You are better read in my affairs than I am, that is all I have to answer, I will go with you, and willingly, and what you think most dangerous, I will sit and laugh at. For sister it is not folly but good discretion governs our maine fortunes.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: I am glad to hear you say so.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: I am for you.

body.stage: Enter Shorthose and Humphrey with riding rods.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: The devil cannot stay her, she will on it, eat an egg now, and then we must away.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: I am galled already, yet I will pray may London ways from henceforth be full of holes, and Coaches crack their wheels, may zealous Smiths so housel all our Hackneys, that they feel compunction in their feet, and tire at Highgate, may it rain above all Almanacs till carriers sail, and the Kings Fishmonger ride like Bike Arion upon a Trout to London.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: At S. Albanes, let all the Inns be drunk, not an Host sober to bid her worship welcome.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: Not a Fiddle, but all preached down with Puritans; no meat but legs of beef.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: No beds but Wool-packs.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: And those so crammed with warrens of starved Fleas that bite like bandogs; let Mims be angry at their S. Bellswagger, and we pass in the heat on it and be beaten, beaten abominably, beaten horse and man, and all my Ladies linen sprinkled with suds and dish water.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: Not a wheel but out of joint.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Why dost thou laugh.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: There is a Gentleman, and the rarest Gentleman, and makes the rarest sport.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: Where, where?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Within here, has made the gayest sport with Tom the Coachman, so tewed him up with sack that he lies lashing a butt of Malmsie for his Mares.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: It is very good.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: And talks and laughs, and singes the rarest songs, and Shorthose, he has so mauled the red Deer pies, made such an alms in the buttery.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: Better still.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: My Lady in a rage with the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: May he anger her into a feather.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I pray tell me, who sent you hither? for I imagine it is not your condition, you look so temperately, and like a Gentleman, to ask me these mild questions.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Do you think I use to walk of errands, gentle Lady, or deal with women out of dreams from others.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: You have not known me sure:

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Not much.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: What reason have you then to be so tender of my credit, you are no kinsman.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: If you take it so, the honest office that I came to do you, is not so heavy but I can return it: now I perceive you are too proud, not worth my visit.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Pray stay, a little proud.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Monstrous proud, I grieve to hear a woman of your value, and your abundant parts stung by the people, but now I see it is true, you look upon me as if I were a rude and saucy fellow that borrowed all my breeding from a dunghill, or such a one, as should now fall and worship you in hope of pardon: you are cozened Lady, I came to prove opinion a loud liar, to see a woman only great in goodness, and Mistress of a greater fame than fortune, but ~~

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You are a strange Gentleman, if I were proud now, I should be monstrous angry, which I am not, and show the effects of pride; I should despise you, but you are welcome sir: To think well of ourselves, if we deserve it, is a luster in us, and every good we have, strives to show gracious, what use is it else, old age like Seer trees, is seldom seen affected, stirs sometimes at rehearsal of such acts as his daring youth endeavoured.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: This is well, and now you speak to the purpose, you please me, but to be place proud:

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: If it be our own, why are we set here with distinction else, degrees, and orders given us, in you men, it is held a coolness, if you lose your right, affronts and loss of honour: streets, and walls, and upper ends of tables, had they tongues could tell what blood has followed, and what fude about your ranks; are we so much below you, that till you have us, are the tops of nature, to be accounted drones, without a difference, you will make us beasts indeed.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Nay worse than this too, proud of your clothes, they swear a Mercers Lucifer, a tumer tacked together by a Taylor, nay yet worse, proud of red and white, a varnish that buttermilk can better.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Lord how little will vex these poor blind people, if my clothes be sometimes gay and glorious, does it follow my mind must be my Mercers too, or say my beauty please some weak eyes, must it please them to think, that blows me up, that every hour blows of: this is an Infants anger.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Thus they say too, what though you have a Coach lined through with velvet, and four fair Flaunders Mares, why should the streets be troubled continually with you, till Carmen curse you, can there be aught in this but pride of show Lady, and pride of bum-beating, till the learned lawyers with their fat bags, are thrust against the bulks till all their Cases crack; why should this Lady, and the other Lady, and the third sweet Lady, and Madam at mile end, be daily visited, and your poorer neighbours, with course napses neglected, fashions conferred about, pouncings, and paintings, and young men's bodies read on like Anatomies.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You are very credulous, and somewhat desperate to deliver this sir, to her you know not, but you shall confess me, and find I will not start; in us all meetings lie open to these lewd reports, and our thoughts at Church, our very meditations some will swear, which all should fear to judge, at least uncharitably, are mingled with your memories, cannot sleep, but this sweet Gentleman swims in our fancies, that scarlet man of war, and that smooth Senior; not dress our heads without new ambushes, how to surprise that greatness or that glory; our very smiles are subject to constructions; nay sir, it is come to this, we cannot pish, but it is a favour for some fool or other: should we examine you thus, were it not possible to take you without Prospectives.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: It may be, but these excuse not.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Nor yours force no truth sir, what deadly tongues you have, and to those tongues what hearts, and what inventions; ah my conscience, and it were not for sharpe justice, you would venture to aim at your own mothers, and account it glory to say you had done so; all you think are Counsels and cannot err, it is we still that show double, giddy, or gorged with passion; we that build Babels for men's conclusions, we that scatter, as day does his warm light; our killing curses over Gods creatures, next to the devil's malice: let us entreat your good words.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Well, this woman has a brave soul.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Are not we gaily blessed then, and much beholding to you for your substance; you may do what you list, we what beseems us, and narrowly do that too, and precisely, our names are served in else at Ordinaries, and belched abroad, in Taverns.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O most brave Wench, and able to redeem an age of women.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You are no Whoremasters, alas, no, Gentlemen, it were an impudency to think you vicious; you are so holy, handsome Ladies fright you, you are the cool things of the time, the temperance, mere emblems of the Law, and vales of Virtue, you are not daily mending like Dutch Watches, and plastering like old walls; they are not Gentlemen, that with their secret sins increase our Surgeons, and lie in foreign Countries, for new sores; women are all these vices; you are not envious, false, covetous, vainglorious, irreligious, drunken, revengeful, giddy-eyed, like Parrots, eaters of others honours.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You are angry.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: No by my troth, and yet I could say more too, for when men make me angry, I am miserable.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Sure it is a man she could not bear it thus bravely else, it may be I am tedious.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Not at all sir, I am content at this time you should trouble me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You are distrustful.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Where I find no truth sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Come, come, you are full of passion.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Some I have, I were too near the nature a God else.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You are monstrous peevish.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Because they are monstrous foolish, and know not how to use that should try me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I was never answered thus, was you never drunk Lady?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: No sure, not drunk sir? yet I love good wine as I love health and joy of heart, but temperately, why do you ask that question?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: For that sin that they most charge you with, is this sins servant, they say you are monstrous.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: What, sir, what?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Most strangely.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: It has a name sure.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Infinitely lustful, without all bounds, they swear you killed your husband.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Let us have it all for heavens sake, it is good mirth sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: They say you will have four now, and those four stuck in four quarters like four winds to cool you; will she not cry nor curse?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: On with your Story.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And that you are forcing out of dispensations with sums of money to that purpose.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Four husbands, should not I be blessed sir; for example, Lord what should I do with them, turn a Malt mill, or tithe them out like town Bulls to my tenants, you come to make me angry, but you cannot.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I will make you merry then, you are a brave woman, and in despite of envy a right one, go thy ways, truth thou art as good a woman, as any Lord of them all can lay his leg over, I do not often commend your sex.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: It seems so, your commendations are so studied for.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I came to see you, and sift you into flower, to know your pureness, and I have found you excellent I thank you; continue so, and show men how to tread, and women how to follow: get an husband, an honest man, you are a good woman, and live hedged in from scandal, let him be too an understanding man, and to that steadfast; it is pity your fair Figure should miscarry, and then you are fixed, farewell.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Pray stay a little, I love your company now you are so pleasant, and to my disposition set so even.

sp.speaker: Ua.
sp.l: I can no longer.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: As I live a fine fellow, this manly handsome bluntness; shows him honest; what is he, or from whence? bless me, four husbands, how prettily he fooled me into vices, to stir my jealousy, and find my nature, a proper Gentleman, I am not well of the sudden, such a companion I could live and die with, his angers are mere mirth.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Come, come, I am ready.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Are you so?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: What ails she, the Coach stays, and the people, the day goes on, I am as ready now as you desire sister: fie, who stays now, why do you sit and pout thus.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Prithee be quiet, I am not well.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: For heavens sake let us not ride staggering in the night, come, pray you take some sweet meats in your pocket, if your stomach ~~

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: I have a little business.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: To abuse me, you shall not find new dreams, and new suspicions, to horse withal.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Lord who made you a Commander: hey ho, my heart.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Is the wind come thither, and coward like, do you lose your colours to them, are you sick of the Valentine; sweet sister, come let us away, the country will so quicken you, and we shall live so sweetly: my Luce, Ladies cloak, nay, you have put me into such a gog of going I would not stay for all the world; if I live here, you have so knocked this love into my head, that I shall love anybody, and I find my body, I know not how, so apt; pray let us be gone sister, I stand on thorns.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I prithee Isabella, I in faith I have some business that concerns me, I will suspect no more, here, wear that for me, and I will pay the hundred pound you owe your tailor.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: I had rather go, but ~~

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Come walk within me, we will go to Cards, unsaddle the horses.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: A Jubilee, a Jubilee, we stay boys.

body.stage: Enter Uncle, Lance, Fountaine, Bellamore, Harebraine following.

sp.speaker: Unc.
sp.l: Are they behind us?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Close, close, speak aloud sir.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.l: I am glad my nephew has so much discretion at length to find his wants: did she entertain him.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.l: Most bravely, nobly, and gave him such a welcome.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.l: For his own sake do you think.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Most certain sir, and in his own cause bestirred himself too, and wan such liking from her, she dotes on him, has the command of all the house already.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.l: He deals not well with his friends.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.l: Let him deal on, and be his own friend, he has most need of her.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.l: I wonder they would put him.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: You are in the right on it, a man that must raise himself, I knew he would cousin them, and glad I am he has, he watched occasion, and found it in the nick.

sp.speaker: Unc.
sp.l: He has deceived me.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: I told you howsoever he wheeled about, he would charge whom at length, how I could laugh now, to think of these tame fools.

sp.speaker: Unc.
sp.l: It was not well done, because they trusted him, yet.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Hark you Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.l: We are upon a business, pray excuse us, they have it home.

sp.speaker: Lanc.
sp.l: Come let it work good on Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Fount.
sp.l: It is true, he is a knave, I ever thought it.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.l: And we are fools, tame fools.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Come let us go seek him, he shall be hanged before he colt us basely.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Art sure she loves him.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Am I sure I live? And I have clap on such a commendation on your revenge.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Faith, he is a pretty Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Handsome enough, and that her eye has found out;

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: He talks the best they say, and yet the maddest.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Has the right way.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: How is she?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Bears it well, as if she cared not, but a man may see with half an eye through all her forced behaviours, and find who is her Vallentine.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Come let us go see her, I long to prosecute.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: By no means Mistress, let her take better hold first,

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: I could burst now.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p: Upbraid me with your benefits, you Pilchers, you shotten, sold, slight fellows, was it not I that undertook you first from empty barrels, and brought those barking mouths that gaped like bung-holes to utter sense? where got you understanding? who taught you manners and apt carriage to rank yourselves? who filled you in fit Taverns, were those borne with your worships when you came hither? what brought you from the Universities of moment matter to allow you, besides your small bare sentences?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: It is well sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Long cloaks with two hand-rapiers, boot-hoses with penny poses, and twenty fools opinions, who looked on you but piping rites that knew you would be prising, and Prentices in Paules Church-yard, that scented your want of Brittanes Books.

sp.speaker: Fount.
sp.l: This cannot save you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Taunt my integrity you whelps?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: You may talk the stock we gave you out, but see no further.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.p: You tempt our patience, we have found you out, and what your trust comes to, ye are well feathered, thank us, and think now of an honest course, it is time; men now begin to look, and narrowly into your tumbling tricks, they are stale.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Is not that he?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: It is he.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Be still and mark him.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.p: How miserable will these poor wretches be when I forsake them, but things have their necessities, I am sorry, to what a vomit must they turn again , now to their own dear dunghill breeding; never hope after I cast you off, you men of Motley, you most undone things below pity, any that has a soul and six pence dares relieve you, my name shall bar that blessing; there is your cloak sir, keep it close to you, it may yet preserve you a fortnight longer from the fool; your hat, pray be covered, and there is the satin that your worships sent me, will serve you at a sizer yet.

sp.speaker: Fount.
sp.l: Nay faith sir, you may even rub these out now.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: No such relic, nor the least rag of such a sordid weakness shall keep me warm, these breeches are mine own, purchased, and paid for, without your compassion, and Christian bleaches founded in Black Friars, and so I will maintain them.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.l: So they seem sir.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.p: Only the thirteen shillings in these breeches, and the odd groat, I take it, shall be yours sir, a mark to know a knave by, pray preserve it, do not displease me more, but take it presently, now help me off with my Boots.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.l: We are no grooms sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: For once you shall be, do it willingly, or by this hand I will make you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: To our own sir, we may apply our hands.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: There is your hangers, you may deserve a strong pair, and a girdle will hold you without buckles; now I am perfect, and now the proudest of your worships tell me I am beholding to you.

sp.speaker: Fount.
sp.l: No such matter.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.p: And take heed how you pity me, it is dangerous, exceeding dangerous, to prate of pity which are the poorer; you are now puppies; I without you, or you without my knowledge be rogues, and so be gone, be rogues and reply not, for if you do ~~

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Only thus much, and then we will leave you, the air is far sharper than our anger sir, and these you may reserve to rail in warmer.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.l: Pray have a care sir of your health.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Yes hoghounds, more than you can have of your wits; it is cold, and I am very sensible, extremely cold too, yet I will not off, till I have shamed these rascals; I have endured as ill heats as another, and every way if one could perish my body, you will bear the blame on it; I am colder here, not a poor penny left.

sp.speaker: Unc.
sp.l: It Has taken rarely, and now he is flayed he will be ruled.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.l: To him, tew him, abuse him, and nip him close.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.l: Why how now cousin, sunning yourself this weather?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: As you see sir, in a hot sit, I thank my friends.

sp.speaker: Unc.
sp.p: But cousin, where are your clothes man, those are no inheritance, your scruple may compound with those I take it, this is no fashion cousin.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: Not much followed, I must confess; yet Uncle I determine to try what may be done next Term.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.l: How came you thus, sir, for you are strangely moved.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.p: Rags, toys and trifles, fit only for those fools that first possessed them, and to those Knaves, they are rendered freemen, Uncle, ought to appear like innocents, old Adam, a fair Fig-leaf sufficient.

sp.speaker: Vncle.
sp.l: Take me with you, were these your friends, that cleared you thus?

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: Hang friends, and even reckonings that make friends.

sp.speaker: Unc.
sp.p: I thought till now, there had been no such living, no such purchase, for all the rest is labour, as a list of honourable friends, do not such men as you sir in lieu of all your understandings, travels, and those great gifts of nature; aim at no more than casting off your coats, I am strangely cozened.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Should not the town shake at the cold you feel now, and all the Gentry suffer interdiction, no more sense spoken, all things Goth and Vandal, till you be summed again, velvets and scarlets, anointed with gold lace, and cloth of silver turned into Spanish Cottons for a penance, wits blasted with your bulls, and Taverns withered, as though the term lay at S Albans.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Gentlemen you have spoken long, and level, I beseech you take breath a while and hear me, you imagine now, by the twirling of your strings, that I am at the last, as also that my friends are flown like Swallows after Summer.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: And that I have no more in this poor pannier, to raise me up again above your rents Uncle.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.l: All this I do believe.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You have no mind to better me.

sp.speaker: Unc.
sp.l: Yes cousin, and to that end I come, and once more offer you all that my power is master of.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: A match then, lay me down fifty pound there.

sp.speaker: Unc.
sp.l: There it is sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And on it write, that you are pleased to give this, as due unto my merit, without caution of land redeeming, tedious thanks, or thrift hereafter to be hoped for.

sp.speaker: Unc.
sp.l: How?

body.stage: Luce lays a suite and letter at the doore.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: Without daring, when you are drunk, to relish of revilings, to which you are prone in sack Uncle.

sp.speaker: Unc.
sp.l: I thank you sir.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Come, come away, let the young wanton play a while, away I say sir, let him go forward with his naked fashion, he will seek you tomorrow; goodly weather, sultry hot, sultry, how I sweat.

sp.speaker: Vncl.
sp.l: Farewell sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Would I sweat too, I am monstrous vexed, and cold too; and these are but thin pumps to walk the streets in; clothes I must get, this fashion will not fadge with me, besides, it is an ill winter wear, ~~ What art thou? yes, they are clothes, and rich ones, some fool has left them: and if I should utter ~~ what is this paper here; let these be only worn, by the most noble and deserving Gentleman Valentine, ~~ dropped out of the clouds; I think they are full of gold too; well, I will leave my wonder, and be warm again, in the next house I will shift.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Why do you deal thus with him it is unnobly.

sp.speaker: Unc.
sp.p: Peace cousin peace, you are too tender of him, he must be dealt thus with, he must be cured thus, the violence of his disease Francisco, must not be jested with, it is grown infectious, and now strong corrosives most cure him.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.l: Has had a stinger, has eaten off his Clothes, the next his skin comes.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.l: And let it search him to the bones, it is better, it will make him feel it.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.l: Where be his noble friends now? will his fantastical opinions cloth him, or the learned Art of having nothing feed him.

sp.speaker: Unc.
sp.p: It must needs greedily, for all his friends have slung him off, he is naked, and where to skin himself again, if I know, or can devise how he should get himself lodging, his spirit must be bowed, and now we have him, have him at that we hoped for.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Next time we meet him cracking of Nuts, with half a clock about him, for all means are cut off, or borrowing six pence, to show his bounty in the pottage Ordinary.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Which way went he?

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Pox, Why should you ask after him, you have been trimmed already, let him take his fortune, he spun it out himself, sir, there is no pity.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.l: Besides some good to you now from this misery.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I rise upon his ruins, fie, fie, Uncle, fie honest Lance, those Gentlemen were base people, that could so soon take fire to his destruction.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.l: You are a fool, you are fool, a young man.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: Morrow Uncle, morrow sweet Francke and how, and how do ye, think now, how show matters; morrow Bandog.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Is this man naked, forsaken of his friends?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Thou art handsome Francke, a pretty Gentleman, in faith thou lookest well, and yet here may be those that look as handsome.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.l: Sure he can conjure, and has the devil for his taylor.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.l: New and rich, it is most impossible he should recover.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Give him this luck, and fling him into the Sea.

sp.speaker: Unc.
sp.l: It is not he, imagination cannot work this miracle.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.p: Yes, yes, it is he, I will assure you Uncle, the very he, the he your wisdom played withal, I thank you for it, neighed at his nakedness, and made his cold and poverty, your pastime; you see I live, and the best can do no more Uncle, and though I have no state, I keep the streets still; and take my pleasure in the town, like a poor Gentleman, wear clothes to keep me warm, poor things they serve me, can make a show too if I list, yes Uncle, and ring a peal in my pockets, ding dong, Uncle, these are mad foolish ways, but who can help them .

sp.speaker: Unc.
sp.l: I am amazed.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: I will sell my copyhold, for since there are such excellent new nothings, why should I labour, is there no fairy haunts him, no rat, nor no old woman.

sp.speaker: Unc.
sp.l: You are Vallentine.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I think so, I cannot tell, I have been called so, and some say christened, why do you wonder at me, and swell, as if you had met a sergeant fasting, did you ever know desert want, you are fools, a little stoop there may be to allay him, he would grow too rank else, a small eclipse, to shadow him, but out he must break, glowingly again, and with a great luster, look you Uncle, motion, and Majesty.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.l: I am confounded.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I am of his faith.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.p: Walk by his careless kinsman, and turn again and walk, and look thus Uncle, taking someone by the hand, he loves best, leave them to the mercy of the hog market, come Francke, Fortune is now my friend, let me instruct thee.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Good morrow Uncle, I must needs go with him.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.p: Flay me, and turn me out where none inhabits, within two hours, I shall be thus again, now wonder on, and laugh at your own ignorance.

sp.speaker: Unc.
sp.l: I do believe him.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: So do I, and heartily upon my conscience bury him stark naked, he would rise again, within two hours embroidered: sow mustard seeds, and they cannot come up so thick as his new satins do, and clothes of silver, there is no striving.

sp.speaker: Unc.
sp.l: Let him play a while then, and let us search out what hand: ~~

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Aye there the game lies.

sp.speaker: Foun.
sp.p: Come let us speak for ourselves, we have lodged him sure enough, his nakedness dare not peep out to cross us.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: We can have no admittance.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.p: Let us in boldly, and use our best arts, who she deigns to favour, we are all content.

sp.speaker: Foun.
sp.l: Much good may do her with him, no civil wars.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: By no means, now do I wonder in what old tod Ivy he lies whistling for means, nor clothes he has none, nor none will trust him, we have made that side sure, teach him a new wooing.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.l: Say it is his Uncles spite.

sp.speaker: Foun.
sp.p: It is all one Gentlemen, it has rid us of a fair encumbrance, and makes us look about to our own fortunes. Who are these?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Not see this man yet, well, I shall be wiser: but Luce didst ever know a woman melt so, she is finely hurt to hunt.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Peace, the three suitors.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I could so titter now and laugh, I was lost Luce, and I must love, I know not what; O Cupid, what pretty gins thou hast to halter woodcocks, and we must into the Country in all haste Luce.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: For heavens sake Mistress.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Nay I have done, I must laugh though, but scholar, I shall teach you.

sp.speaker: Foun.
sp.l: It is her sister.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Save you Ladies.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Fair met Gentlemen, you are visiting my sister, I assure myself.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.l: We would fain bless our eyes.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Behold and welcome, you would see her:

sp.speaker: Foun.
sp.l: It is our business.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: You shall see her, and you shall talk with her.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: She will not see them, nor spend a word.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: I will make her fret a thousand, nay now I have found the scab, I will so scratch her.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: She cannot endure them.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: She loves them but too dearly, come follow me, I will bring you to the party Gentlemen, then make your own conditions.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: She is sick you know.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I will make her well, or kill her, and take no idle answer, you are fools then, nor stand off for her state, she will scorn you all then, but urge her still, and though she fret, still follow her, a widow must be won so.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: She speaks bravely.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I would fain have a brother in law, I love men's company, and if she call for dinner to avoid you, be sure you stay; follow her into her chamber, if she retire to pray, pray with her, and boldly, like honest lovers.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: This will kill her.

sp.speaker: Foun.
