sp.l: You have showed us one way, do but lend the the other.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: I know you stand a thorns, come I will dispatch you.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: If you live after this.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: I have lost my aim.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Did you not see them since.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No hang them, hang them.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Nor will you not be seen by them:

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Let them alone Francke, I will make, them their own justice, and a jerker.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Such base discourteous dog whelps.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: I shall dog them, and double dog them, ere I have done.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Will you go with me, for I would fain find out this piece of bounty, it was the widows man, that I am certain of.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: To what end would you go.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: To give thanks sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Hang giving thanks, hast not thou parts deserves it, it includes a further will to be beholding, beggars can do no more at doors, if you will go, there lies your way.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I hope you will go.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: No not in ceremony, and to a woman, with mine own father, were he living Francke; I would to the Court with bears first, if it be that wench, I think it is, for the others wiser, I would not be so looked upon, and laughed at, so made a ladder for her wit, to climb upon, for it is the tartest tit in Christendom, I know her well Francke, and have buckled with her, so licked, and stroked, leared upon, and flouted, and shown to Chambermaids, like a strange beast, she had purchased with her penny.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: You are a strange man, but do you think it was a woman

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.p: There is no doubt on it, who can be there to do it else, besides the manner of the circumstances.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Then such courtesies, who ever does them sir, saving your own wisdom, must be more looked into, and better answered, than with deserving slights, or what we ought to have conferred upon us, men may starve else, means are not gotten now, with crying out I am a gallant fellow, a good soldier, a man of learning, or fit to be employed, immediate blessings, cease like miracles, and we must grow, by second means, I pray go with me, even as you love me sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I will come to thee, but Francke, I will not stay to hear your fopperies, dispatch those ere I come.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: You will not fail me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Some two hours hence expect me.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I thank you, and will look for you.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Who let me in these puppies, you blind rascals, you drunken knaves several.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: Yes forsooth, I will let them in presently, ~~ gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Spercious you blown pudding, bawling rogue.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: I bawl as loud as I can, would you have me fetch them upon my back.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Get them out rascal, out with them, out, I sweat to have them near me.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: I should sweat more to carry them out.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.l: They are Gentlemen Madam:

sp.speaker: Shor.
sp.l: Shall we get them into the buttery, and make them drink.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Do anything, so I be eased.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Now to her sir, fear nothing.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Slip aside boy, I know she loves them, howsoever she carries it, and has invited them, my young Mistress told me so.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: Away to tables then.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: I shall burst with the sport on it.

sp.speaker: Fount.
sp.l: You are too curious Madam, too full of preparation, we expect it not.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Methinks the house is handsome, every place decent, what need you be vexed.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.l: We are no strangers.

sp.speaker: Foun.
sp.p: What though we come ere you expected us, do not we know your entertainments Madam are free, and full at all times.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: You are merry Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ball.
sp.l: We come to be merry Madam, and very merry, men live to laugh heartily, and now and then Lady a little of our old plea.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: I am busy, and very busy too, will none deliver me.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.l: There is a time for all, you may be busy, but when your friends come, you have as much power Madam.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: This is a tedious torment.

sp.speaker: Foun.
sp.p: How handsomely this title piece of anger shows upon her, well Madam well, you know not how to grace yourself.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Nay everything she does breeds a new sweetness.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I must go up, I must go up, I have a business waits upon me, some wine for the Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.l: Nay, we will go with you, we never saw your chambers yet.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Hold there boys.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Say I go to my prayers?

sp.speaker: Foun.
sp.l: We will pray with you, and help your meditations.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: This is boisterous, or say I go to sleep, will you go to sleep with me?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: So suddenly before meat will be dangerous, we know your dinner is ready Lady, you will not sleep.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Give me my Coach, I will take the air.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.l: We will wait on you, and then your meat after a quickened stomach.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Let it alone, and call my steward to me, and bid him bring his reckonings into the Orchard, these unmannerly rude puppies ~~

sp.speaker: Foun.
sp.l: We will walk after you and view the pleasure of the place.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Let her not rest, for if you give her breath, she will scorn and sloute you, seem how she will, this is the way to win her, be bold and prosper.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Nay if we do not tire her. ~~

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I will teach you to worm me good Lady sister, and peep into my privacies, to suspect me, I will torture you, with that you hate most daintily, and when I have done that, laugh at that you love most.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: What have you done, she chases and fumes outrageously, and still they persecute her.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Long may they do so, I will teach her to declaim against my pities, why is she not gone out of the town, but gives occasion for men to run mad after her.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I shall be hanged.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: This in me had been high treason, three at a time, and private in her Orchard, I hope she will cast her reckonings right now.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Well, I shall find who brought them.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Why do you laugh sister, I fear me it is your trick, it was neatly done of you, and well becomes your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: What have you done with them.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Locked them in the Orchard, there I will make them dance and caper too, before they get their liberty, unmannerly rude puppies.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: They are somewhat saucy, but yet I will let them out, and once more hound them, why were they not beaten out.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: I was about it, but because they came as suitors.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Why did you not answer them.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: They are so impudent they will receive none: More yet, how came these in?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: At the door, Madam.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: It is that face.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: This is the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: She sent the money too.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: The same.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: I will leave you, they have some business.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Nay you shall stay sister, they are strangers both to me; how her face alters.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: I am sorry he comes now.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: I am glad he is here now though, who would you speak with, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: You Lady, or your fair sister there, here is a Gentleman, that has received a benefit.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: From whom sir.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: From one of you, as he supposes Madam, your man delivered it.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: I pray go forward.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: And of so great a goodness, that he dares not, without the tender of his thanks and service, pass by the house.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Which is the Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: This Madam.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: What is your name Sir?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: They that know me call me Franscisco Lady, one not so proud to scorn, so timely a benefit, nor so wretched, to hide a gratitude.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: It is well bestowed then.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Your fair self, or your sister as it seems, for what desert I dare not know, Unless a handsome subject for your charities, or aptness in your noble wills to do it, have showered upon my wants, a timely bounty, which makes me rich in thanks, my best inheritance.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I am sorry it was not mine, this is the Gentlewoman, fie do not blush, go roundly to the matter, the man is a pretty man.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: You have three fine ones.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Then to you dear Lady.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: I pray no more Sir, if I may persuade you, your only aptness to do this is recompense, and more than I expected.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: But good Lady.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: And for me further to be acquainted with it, besides the imputation of vain glory, were greedy thankings of myself, I did it not to be more affected to; I did it, and if it happened where I thought it fitted, I have my end, more to enquire is curious in either of us, more than that suspicious:

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: But gentle Lady, it will be necessary.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: About the right way nothing, do not fright it, being to pious use and tender sighted, with the blown face of complements, it blasts it had you not come at all, but thought thanks, it had been too much, it was not to see your person.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: A brave dissembling rogue, and how she carries it.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Though I believe few handsomer; or hear you, though I affect a good tongue well; or try you, though my years desire a friend, that I relieved you.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: A plaguey cunning quean.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: For so I carried it, my end is too glorious in mine eyes, and bartered the goodness I propounded with opinion.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Fear her not Sir.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: You cannot catch me sister.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Will you both teach, and tie my tongue up Lady?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Let it suffice you have it, it was never mine, whilst good men wanted it.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: This is a Saint sure.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: And if you be not such a one restore it.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: To commend myself, were more officious than you think my thanks are, to doubt I may be worth your gift a treason, both to mine own good, and understanding, I know my mind clear, and though modesty tells me, he that entreats intrudes, yet I must think something, and of some season, met with your better taste, this had not been else.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: What ward for that, Wench?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Alas it never touched me.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Well gentle Lady, yours is the first money I ever took upon a forced ill manners.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: The last of me, if ever you use other.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: How may I do, and your way to be thought a grateful taker?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Spend it and say nothing, your modesty may deserve more.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: O sister, will you bar thankfulness?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Dogs dance for meat, would you have men do worse, for they can speak, cry out like Woodmongers, good deeds by the hundreds, I did it that my best friend should not know it, wine and vain glory does as much as I else, if you will force my merit, against my meaning, use it in well bestowing it, in showing it came to be a benefit, and was so; and not examining a woman did it, or to what end, in not believing sometimes yourself, when drink and stirring conversation may ripen strange persuasions.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Gentle Lady, I were a base receiver of a courtesy, and you a worse disposer, were my nature unfurnished of these foresights, Ladies honours were ever in my thoughts, unspotted crimes, their good deeds holy temples, where the incense burns not, to common eyes your fears are virtuous, and so I shall preserve them.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Keep but this way, and from this place to tell me so, you have paid me; and so I wish you see all fortune.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: fear not, the woman will be thanked, I do not doubt it, are you so crafty, carry it so precisely, this is to wake my fears, or to abuse me, I shall look narrowly, despair not Gentlemen, there is an hour to catch a woman in, if you be wise, so, I must leave you too; now will I go laugh at my suitors.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Sir what courage

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: This woman is a founder, and cites statutes to all her benefits.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: I never knew yet, so few years and so cunning, yet believe me she has an itch, but how to make her confess it, for it is a crafty tit, and plays about you, will not bite home, she would fain, but she dares not; carry yourself but so discreetly Sir, that want or wantonness seem not to search you, and you shall see her open.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I do love her, and were I rich, would give two thousand pound to wed her wit but one hour, O it is a dragon, and such a sprightly way of pleasure, ha Lance.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Your ha Lance broken once, you would cry, ho, ho, Lance.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Some leaden landed rogue will have this wench now, when all is done, some such youth will carry her, and wear her greasy out like stuff, some dunce that knows no more but Markets, and admires nothing but a long charge at sises: O the fortunes.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Comfort yourself.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: They are here yet, and a love too, boldly upon it Nay Mistress, I still told you, how I would find your trust, this it is to venture your charity upon a boy.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Now, what is the matter? stand fast, and like yourself.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Prithee no more wench.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: What was his want to you.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: It is true.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Or misery, or say he had been in the Cage, was there no mercy to look abroad but yours.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: I am paid for fooling.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Must every slight companion that can purchase a show of poverty and beggarly planet fall under your compassion.

sp.speaker: Lanc.
sp.l: Here is a new matter.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Nay you are served but too well, here he stays yet, yet as I live.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: How her face alters on me?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Out of a confidence I hope.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: I am glad on it.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: How do you gentle Lady?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Much ashamed sir, but first stand further off me, you are infectious to find such vanity, nay almost impudence, where I believe a worth: is this your thanks, the gratitude you were so mad to make me, your trim council Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Lanc.
sp.l: What Lady?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Take your device again, it will not serve sir, the woman will not bite, you are finely cozened, drop it no more for shame.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Do you think you are here sir amongst your waistcoateers. your base Wenches that scratch at such occasions; you are deluded; This is a Gentlewoman of a noble house, born to a better same than you can build her, and eyes above your pitch.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I do acknowledge ~~

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Then I beseech you sir, what could you see, speak boldly, and speak truly, shame the devil, in my behaviour of such easiness that you durst venture to do this.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: You amaze me, this Ring is none of mine, nor did I drop it.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: I saw you drop it sir.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: I took it up too, still looking when your modesty should miss it, why what a childish part was this?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I vow.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Vow me no vows, he that dares do this, has bred himself to boldness, to forswear too; there take your gewgaw, you are too much pampered, and I repent my part, as you grow older grow wiser if you can, and so farewell sir.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Grow wiser if you can, she has put it to you, it is a rich Ring, did you drop it?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Never, never see it before Lance.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Thereby hangs a tail then: what slight she makes to catch herself look up sir, you cannot lose her if you would, how daintily she flies upon the lure, and cunningly she makes her stops, whistle and she will come to you.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I would I were so happy.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Maids are clocks, the greatest wheel they show, goes slowest to us, and makes us hang on tedious hopes the lesser, which are concealed being often oiled with wishes flee like desires, and never leave that motion, till the tongue strikes; she is flesh, blood, and marrow, young as her purpose, and soft as pity; no Monument to worship, but a mold to make men in, a neat one, and I know how ever she appears now, which is near enough, you are stark blind if you hit not soon at night; she would venture forty pounds more but to feel a flea in your shape bite her drop no more Rings forsooth, this was the prettiest thing to know her heart by.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Thou puttest me in much comfort.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Put yourself in good comfort, if she do not point you out the way, drop no more rings, she will drop herself into you.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I wonder my brother comes not.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Let him alone, and feed yourself on your own fortunes; come be frolic, and let us be monstrous wise and full of council, drop no more Rings.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: If you will needs be foolish you must be used so: who sent for you? who entertained you Gentlemen? who bid you welcome hither? you came crowding, and impudently bold; press on my patience, as if I kept a house for all Companions, and of all sorts: will I have your wills, will ye vex me and force my liking from you, I never owed you?

sp.speaker: Fount.
sp.l: For all this we will dine with you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: And for all this will have a better answer from you.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You shall never, neither have an answer nor dinner, unless you use me with a more staid respect, and stay your time too.

body.stage: Enter Isabella, Shorthose, Roger, Humphrey, Ralph, with dishes of meat.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Forward with the meat now.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Come gentlemen march fairly.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Roger, you are a weak Serving-man, your white broth runs from you; fie, how I sweat under this pile of Beef; an Elephant can do more, O for such a back now, and in these times, what might a man arrive at; Goose, graze you up, and Woodcock march behind thee, I am almost foundered.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Who bid you bring the meat yet? away you knaves, I will not dine these two hours, how am I vexed and chased; go carry it back and tell the Cook, he is an arrant Rascal, to send before I called.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: Faces about Gentlemen, beat a mournful march then, and give some supporters, or else I perish ~~

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: It does me much good to see her chase thus.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.p: We can stay Madam, and will stay and dwell here, it is good Air.

sp.speaker: Foun.
sp.l: I know you have beds enough, and meat you never want.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: You want a little.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: We dare to pretend on, since you are churlish, we will give you physic, you must purge this anger, it burns you and decays you.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: If I had you out once I would be at charge of a percullis for you.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: Good morrow noble Lady.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Good morrow sir, how sweetly now he looks, and how full manly, what slaves was these to use him so.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I come to look a young man I call brother.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Such a one was here sir, as I remember your own brother, but gone almost an hour ago.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: God even then.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You must not so soon sir, here be some Gentlemen, it may be you are acquainted with them.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.l: Will nothing make him miserable?

sp.speaker: Foun.
sp.l: How glorious!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: It is the very he, does it rain fortunes, or has he a familiar.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.l: How doggedly he looks too.

sp.speaker: Foun.
sp.l: I am beyond my faith, pray let us be going.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Where are these Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: Yes I know them, and will be more familiar.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Morrow Madam.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Nay stay and dine.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You shall stay till I talk with you, and not dine neither, but fastingly my fury, you think you have undone me, think so still, and swallow that belief, till you be company for Court-hand Clerks, and starved Attorneys, till you break in at plays like Prentices for three a groat, and crack nuts with the scholars in penny Rooms again, and fight for Apples, till you return to what I found you, people betrayed into the hands of Fencers, Challengers, Toothdrawers bills, and tedious Proclamations in Meal- markets, with throngings to see Cutpurses: stir not, but hear, and mark, I will cut your throats else, till Waterworks, and rumours of new Rivers rid you again and run you into questions who built Theamea, till you run mad for Lotteries, and stand there with your tables to glean the golden sentences, and cite, them secretly to Serving-men for sound Essays, till Taverns allow you but a Towel room to tipple in wine that the Bell hath gone for twice, and glasses that look like broken promises, tied up with wicker protestations, English Tobacco with half pipes, nor in half a year once burnt, and Biscuit that Bawds have rubbed their gums upon like Corals to bring the mark again; tell these hour rascals so, this most fatal hour will come again, think I sit down the looser.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Will you stay Gentlemen, a piece of beef and a cold Capon, that is all, you know you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: That was cast to abuse us.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Steal off, the devil is in his anger.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Nay I am sure you will not leave me so discourteously now I have provided for you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: What do you hear? why do ye vex a woman of her goodness, her state and worth; can you bring a fair certificate that you deserve to be her footmen, husbands, you puppies, husbands for Whores and Bawds, away you windsuckers; do not look big, nor prate, nor stay, nor grumble, and when you are gone seem to laugh at my fury, and slight this Lady, I shall hear, and know this: and though I am not bound to fight for women, as far as they are good I dare preserve them: be not too bold, for if you be, I will swing you, I will swing you monstrously without all pity, your honours now go, avoid me mainly.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Well sir, you have delivered me, I thank you, and with your nobleness prevented danger, their tongues might utter, will all go and eat sir.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.p: No, no, I dare not trust myself with women, go to your meat, eat little, take less ease, and tie your body to a daily labour, you may live honestly, and so I thank you.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Well go thy ways, thou art a noble fellow, and some means I must work to have thee know it.

sp.speaker: Unc.
sp.l: Most certain it is, her hands that hold him up, and her sister relieves Franke.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I am glad to hear it: but wherefore do they not pursue this fortune to some fair end?

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.l: The women are too crafty, Uellintine too coy, and Franke too bashful, had any wise man hold of such a blessing, they would strike it out of the slint but they would form it.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: The Widow sure, why does she stir so early.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: It is strange, I cannot force him to understand me, and make a benefit, of what I would bring him, tell my sister I will use my devotions at home this morning, she may if she please go to Church.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: Hey ho.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: And do you wait upon her with a torch sir.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: Hey ho.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: You lazy Knave.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: Here is such a tincle tanklings that we can never lie quiet, and sleep our prayers out, Ralph pray empty my right shoe that you made your Chamber pot, and burn a little Rosemary in it, I must wait upon my Lady. This morning Prayer has brought me into a consumption, I have nothing left but flesh and bones about me.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: You drowsy slave, nothing but sleep and swilling.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: Had you been bitten with bandog fleas, as I have been, and haunted with the night Mare.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: With an Alepot.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: You would have little list to morning Prayers, pray take my fellow Ralph, he has a Psalm book, I am an ingram man.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: Get you ready quickly, and when she is ready wait upon her handsomely; no more, be gone.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: If I do snore my part out ~~

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.l: Now to our purposes.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Good morrow Madam.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Good morrow Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Unc.
sp.l: Good joy and fortune.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: These are good things, and worth my thanks, I thank you sir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Much joy I hope you will find, we came to gratulate, your new knit marriage band.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Unc.
sp.l: He is a Gentleman although he be my kinsman, my fair Niece.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Niece sir?

sp.speaker: Unc.
sp.p: Yes Lady, now I may say so, it is no shame to you, I say a Gentleman, and winking at some light fancies, which you most happily may affect him for, as bravely carried, as nobly bred and managed.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: What is all this, I understand you not, what Niece, what marriage knot.

sp.speaker: Unc.
sp.l: I will tell plainly, you are my Niece, and Vallentine the Gentleman has made you so by marriage.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Marriage?

sp.speaker: Unc.
sp.p: Yes Lady, and it was a noble and virtuous part, to take a falling man to your protection, and bay him up again to all his glories.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: The men are mad.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: What though he wanted these outward things, that fly away like shadows, was not his mind a full one, and a brave one, you have wealth enough to give him gloss, and outside; and he wit enough to give way to love a Lady.

sp.speaker: Unc.
sp.l: I ever thought he would do well.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Nay, I knew how ever he wheeled about like a loose Cabin, he would charge home at length, like a brave Gentleman, heavens blessing on your heart Lady, we are so bound to honour you, in all your service so devoted to you.

sp.speaker: Unc.
sp.p: Do not look so strange Widow it must be known, better a general joy; no stirring here yet, come, come you cannot hide them.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Pray be not impudent, these are the finest toys, belike I am married then.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: You are in a miserable estate in the worlds account else, I would not for your wealth it come to doubting.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: And I am great with child?

sp.speaker: Unc.
sp.p: No great they say not, but it is a full opinion you are with child, and great joy among the Gentlemen, your husband hath bestirred himself fairly.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Alas, we know his private hours of entrance, how long, and when he stayed, could name the bed too where he paid down his first fruits.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: I shall believe anon.

sp.speaker: Unc.
sp.p: And we consider for some private reasons, you would have it private, yet take your own pleasure; and so good morrow my best Niece, my sweetest.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: No, no, pray stay.

sp.speaker: Unc.
sp.l: I know you would be with him, love him, and love him well.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: You will find him noble, this may beget ~~

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.l: It must needs work upon her.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: These are fine bobs Infaith , married, and with child too, how long has this been, I trow? they seem grave fellows, they should not come to flout; married, and bedded, the world take notice too, where lies this May game, I could be vexed extremely now, and rail too, but it is to no end, though I itch a little, must I be scratched I know not how, who waits there?

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Make ready my Coach quickly, and wait you only, and hark you sir, be secret and speedy, enquire out where he lies.

sp.speaker: Ral.
sp.l: I shall do it, Madam.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Married, and got with child in a dream, it is fine in faith, sure he that did this, would do better waking

body.stage: Enter Vallentine, Fran. Lance and a boy with a torch.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Hold thy Torch handsomely, :how dost thou Francke, Peter Bassell, bear up.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: You have fried me soundly, Sack do you call this drink.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: A shrewd dog Franck, will bite abundantly.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Now could I fight, and fight with thee.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: With me thou man of Memphis.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: But that thou art mine own natural Master, yet my sack says thou art no man, thou art a Pagan, and pawnest thy land, which a noble cause.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: No arms, nor arms, good Lancelet, dear Lance, no fighting here, we will have Lands boy, Livings, and Titles, thou shalt be a Viceroy, hang fighting, hang it is out of fashion.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: I would fain labour you into your lands again, go to, it is behooveful.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Fie Lance, fie.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: I must beat somebody, and why not my Master, before a stranger, charity and beating begins at home.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: Come thou shalt beat me.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: I will not be compelled, if you were two Masters, I scorn the motion.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Wilt thou sleep.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: I scorn sleep.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Wilt thou go eat.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: I scorn meat, I come for rompering, I come to wait upon my charge discreetly, for look you if you will not take your Mortgage again, here do I lie Saint George, and so forth.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And here do I St. George, bestride the Dragon, thus with my Lance.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: I sting, I sting with my tail.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Do you so, do you so Sir, I shall tail you presently.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: By no means, do not hurt him.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Take this Neilson, and now rise, thou maiden Knight of Malligo, lace on thy helmet of enchanted sack, and charge again.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: I play no more, you abuse me, will you go.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I will bid you good morrow Brother, for sleep I cannot I have a thousand fancies.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.p: Now thou art arrived, go bravely to the matter, and do something of worth Francke.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: You shall hear from us.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: This rogue, if he had been sober, sure had beaten me, is the most tettish knave.

body.stage: Enter Uncle and Merchant: May. with a torch.

sp.speaker: Unc.
sp.l: It is he.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Good morrow.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why sir good morrow to you too, and you be so lusty.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.l: You have made your brother a fine man, we met him.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.p: I made him a fine Gentleman, he was a fool before, brought up amongst the midst of small beer Brew-houses, what would you have with me.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I come to tell you, your latest hour is come.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Are you my sentence.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: The sentence of your state.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Let it be hanged then, and let it be hanged hie enough, I may not see it.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.l: A gracious resolution.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: What would you have else with me, will you go drink, and let the world slide Uncle, ha ha, ha, boys, drink sack like whey boys.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Have you no feeling sir?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Come hither Merchant: make me a supper, thou most reverent Land catcher, a supper of forty pound.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: What then sir?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Then bring thy wife along, and thy fair sisters, thy neighbours and their wives, and all their trinkets, let me have forty trumpets, and such wine, we will laugh at all the miseries of mortgage, and then in state I will render thee an answer.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: What say to this.

sp.speaker: Unc.
sp.l: I dare not say nor think neither.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Will you redeem your state, speak to the point sir.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: Not, not if it were mine heir in the Turks galleys.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Then I must take an order.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Take a thousand, I will not keep it, nor thou shalt not have it, because thou camest in the nick, thou shalt not have it, go take possession, and be sure you hold it, hold fast with both hands, for there be those hounds uncoupled, will ring you such a knell, go down in glory, and march upon my land, and cry, all is mine, cry as the devil did, and be the devil, mark what an echo follows, build fine Marchpanes, to entertain Sir Silkworm and his Lady, and pull the Chapel down, and raise a Chamber for Mistress Silverpin, to lay her belly in, mark what an Earthquake comes, then foolish Merchant my tenants are no subjects, they obey nothing, and they are people too, never Christened, they know no law, nor conscience, they will devour thee: if thou mortal the stopple, they will confound thee, within three days; no bit nor memory of what thou wert, no not the wart upon thy nose there, shall be ever heard of more; go take possession, and bring thy children down, to roast like rabbits, they love young toasts, and butter, Bowbell suckers; as they love mischief, and hate law, they are Cannibals; bring down thy kindred too, that be not fruitful, there be those Mandrakes, that will mollify them, go take possession, I will go to my Chamber, before boy go.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: He is mad sure.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.l: He is half drunk sure, and yet I like this unwillingness to loose it this looking back.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Yes if he did it handsomely, but he is so harsh and strange.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.l: Believe it it is his drink sir, and I am glad his drink has thrust it out.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Cannibals; if ever I come to view his regiments, if fair terms may be had.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: He tells you true sir; They are a bunch of the most boisterous rascals disorder ever made, let them be mad once, the power of the whole Country cannot cool them, be patient but a while.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: As long as you will sir, before I buy a bargain of such runts, I will buy a College for Bears, and live among them .

body.stage: Enter Franscisco, Lance, boy with a torch.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: How dost thou now.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Better than I was, and straighter, but my head is a hogs' head still, it rolls and tumbles.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Thou wert cruelly paid.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: I may live to requite it, put a snaffle of sack in my mouth, and then ride me very well.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: It was all but sport, I will tell thee what I mean now, I mean to see this wench.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Where a devil is she, and there were two, it were better.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Dost thou hear the bell ring?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Yes, yes.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Then she comes to prayers, early each morning thither: Now if I could but meet her, for I am of another mettle now.

body.stage: Enter Isabell, and Shorthose with a Torch.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: What light is yond?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Ha, it is a light, take her by the hand and Court her.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Take her below the girdle, you will never speed else, it comes on this way still, O that I had but such an opportunity in a saw pit, how it comes on, comes on, it is here.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: It is she, fortune I kiss thy hand ~~ good morrow Lady.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: What voice is that sirrah, do you sleep as you go, it is he, I am glad on it, why Shorthose.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: Yes forsooth, I was dreamt, I was going to Church.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: She sees you as plain as I do.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Hold the Torch up.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: Here is nothing but a stall, and a Butchers dog asleep in it, where did you see the voice.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: She looks still angry.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: To her and meet sir.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Here, here.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Yes Lady, never bless yourself, I am but a man, and like an honest man, now I will thank you ~~

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: What do you mean, who sent for you, who desired you

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: Shall I put out the Torch forsooth?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Can I not go about my private meditations, hey, but such companions as you must ruffle me, you had best go with me sir.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: It was my purpose.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Why what an impudence is this, you had best, being so near the Church, provide a Priest, and persuade me to marry you.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: It was my meaning, and such a husband, so loving, and so careful, my youth, and all my fortunes shall arrive at ~~ Hark you.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: It is strange you should be thus unmannerly, turn home again sirrah, you had best now force my man to lead your way.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Yes marry shall he Lady, forward my friend.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: This is a pretty Riot, it may grow to a rape.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Do you like that better, I can ravish you an hundred times, and never hurt you.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: I see nothing, I am asleep still, when you have done tell me, and then I will wake Mistress.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Are you in earnest Sir, do you long to be hanged?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Yes by my troth Lady in these fair tresses.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Shall I call out for help?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: No by no means, that were a weak trick Lady, I will kiss and stop your mouth.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: You will answer all these.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: A thousand kisses more.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: I was never abused thus, you had best give out too, that you found me willing, and say I doted on you.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: That is known already, and no man living shall now carry you from me.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: This is fine in faith.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: It shall be ten times finer.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Well, seeing you are so valiant, keep your way, I will to Church.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: And I will wait upon you.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: And it is most likely there is a Priest, if you dare venture as you profess, I would wish you look about you, to do these rude tricks, for you know their recompenses, and trust not to my mercy.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: But I will Lady.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: For I will so handle you.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: That is it I look for.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Before thou dream.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: Have you done.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Go on sir, and follow if you dare.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: If I do not hang me.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: It is all thine own boy, if it were a million, god a mercy Sack, when would small Beer have done this.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Whose that that knocks and bounces, what a devil ails you, is hell broke loose, or do you keep an Iron mill?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: It is a Gentlewoman sir that must needs speak with you.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.p: A Gentlewoman, what Gentlewoman, what have I to do with Gentlewomen?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: She will not be answered Sir.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: Fling up the bed and let her in, I will try how gentle she is ~~
sp.p: This sack has filled my head so full of babbles, I am almost mad; what Gentlewoman should this be, I hope she has brought me no butter print along with her to lay to my charge, if she have it is all one, I will forswear it.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: O you are a noble gallant, send off your servant pray.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: She will not ravish me, by this light she looks as sharpe set as a Sparrow hawk, what wouldst thou woman.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: O you have used me kindly, and like a Gentleman, this it is to trust to you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Trust to me, for what?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Because I said in jest once, you were a handsome man, one I could like well, and fooling, made you believe I loved you, and might be brought to marry.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: The Widow is drunk too.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You out of this, which is a fine discretion, give out the matter is done, you have won and wed me, and that you have put fairly for an heir too, these are fine rumours to advance my credit; in the name of mischief what did you mean.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.p: That you loved me, and that you might be brought to marry me, why, what a devil do you mean Widow.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: It was a fine trick too, to tell the world though you had enjoyed your first wish, you wished the wealth you aimed at; that I was poor, which is most true, I am, have sold my Lands, because I love not those vexations, yet for mine honours sake, if you must be prating, and for my credits sake in the Town.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I tell thee Widow, I like thee ten times better, now thou hast no Lands, for now thy hopes and cares, lie on thy husband, if thou marriest more.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Have not you married me, and for this main cause, now as you report it, to be your Nurse.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: My Nurse, why, what am I grown to, give me the glass, my Nurse.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You never said truer, I must confess I did a little favour you, and with some labour, might have been persuaded, but when I found I must be hourly troubled, with making broths, and daubing your decays with swaddling, and with stitching up your ruins, for the world so reports.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: Do not provoke me.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: And half an eye may see.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Do not provoke me, the world is a lying world, and thou shalt find it, have a good heart, and take a strong faith to thee, and mark what follows, my Nurse, yes, you shall rock me: Widow I will keep you waking.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: You are disposed sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Yes marry am I Widow, and you shall feel it, nay and they touch my freehold, I am a Tiger.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: I think so.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Come.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Whether.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: Any whether.
The fit is upon me now, the fit is upon me now,
Come quickly gentle Lady, the fit is upon me now,
The world shall know they are fools,
And so shalt thou do too,
Let the Cobbler meddle with his tools,
The fit is upon me now.
sp.p: Take me quickly, while I am in this vain, away with me, for if I have but two hours to consider, all the Widows in the world cannot recover me.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: If you will, go with me sir.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.p: Yes marry will I, but it is in anger yet, and I will marry thee, do not cross me; yes, and I will lie with thee, and get a whole bundle of babies, and I will kiss thee, stand still and kiss me handsomely, but do not provoke me, stir neither hand nor foot, for I am dangerous, I drunk sack yesternight, do not allure me: Thou art no widow of this world, come in pity, and in spite I will marry thee, not a word more, and I may be brought to love thee.

body.stage: Enter Merchant and Vncle at severall doores.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Well met again, and what good news yet.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.l: Faith nothing.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: No fruits of what we sowed.

sp.speaker: Unc.
sp.l: Nothing I hear of.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: No turning in this tide yet.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: It is all flood, and till that fall away, there is no expecting.

body.stage: Enter Fran. Isab. Lance. Shorthose, a torch.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Is not this his younger brother.

sp.speaker: Unc.
sp.p: With a Gentlewoman the Widows sister, as I live he smiles, he has got good hold, why well said Francke in faith, let us stay and mark.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Well you are the prettiest youth, and so you have handled me, think you have me sure.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: As sure as wedlock.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: You had best lie with me too.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Yes indeed will I, and get such black eyed boys.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.l: God a Mercy Francke.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: This is a merry world, poor simple Gentlewomen that think no harm, cannot walk about their business, but they must be catched up I know not how.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I will tell you, and I will instruct you too, have I caught you, Mistress.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Well, if it were not for pure pity, I would give you the slip yet, but being as it is.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: It shall be better.

body.stage: Enter Vallentine, Widow, and Ralph with a torch.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: My sister, as I live, your brother with her, sure, I think you are the Kings takers.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.l: Now it works.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Nay you shall know I am a man.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: I think so.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: And such proof you shall have.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: I pray speak softly.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I will speak it out Widow, yes and you shall confess too, I am no nurse child, I went for a man, a good one, if you can beat me out of the pit.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: I did but jest with you.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: I will handle you in earnest, and so handle you: Nay, when my credit calls.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Are you mad.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: I am mad, I am mad.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Good morrow Sir, I like your preparation.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: Thou hast been at it Francke.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Yes saith, it is done sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Along with me then, never hang an arse, Widow.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: It is to no purpose, sister.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Well said blackebrowes, advance your Torches Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.l: Yes, yes sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And keep your ranks.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Lance carry this before him.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.l: Carry it in state.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What are you, Musicians, I know your coming, and what are those behind you.

sp.speaker: Musi.
sp.l: Gentlemen that sent us to give the Lady, a good morrow.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: O I know them, come boy sing the song I taught you,
And sing it lustily, come forward Gentlemen, you are welcome,
Welcome, now we are all friends, go get the Priest ready,
And let him not be long, we have much business:
Come Francke rejoice with me, thou hast got the start boy,
But I will so tumble after, come my friends lead,
Lead cheerfully, and let your fiddles ring boys,
My follies and my fancies have an end here,
Display the mortgage Lance, Merchant I will pay you,
And everything shall be in joint again.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.l: Afore, afore.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And now confess, and know,
Wit without Money, sometimes gives the blow.
